_prev_prog_3.Description:
All Process Units include:

1- Isomerization 

2- #2 Crude Unit

3- Naphtha/Reformer

4- Merox Treater

5- Polymerization

6- Hydrotreater

7- Mild Hydrocracker and Sour Water Stripper

8- 15MM Hydrogen Plant

9- 5MM Hydrogen Plant

10- Caustic Scrubbing

11- Utilities/Flare System/Flare Gas Scrubber

12- Storage



Preventative program elements that are implemented across all units include: the date on which the safety information was last reviewed as 12/2/2020. 

The techniques used during a PHA or PHA update are checklists and HAZOP. Below is a list of dates of the last PHA or PHA update and the expected or actual completion of all changes resulting from last PHA or PHA update.

  1 (Isomerization) PHA took place on 3/1/2016 and there were no corrective actions identified during the 2016 PHA. 

  2 (Crude) PHA took place on 6/4/2018 and the expected completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update is 7/1/2021

  3 (Naphtha/Reformer) PHA took place on 9/23/2020 and the final report/assignment of corrective actions has not been assigned at this time.

  4 (Merox Treater) PHA took place on 1/24/2017 and the expected completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update is 

  12/31/2021. 

  5 (Polymerization) PHA took place on 5/10/2019 and the expected completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update is 

  7/31/2021.

  6 (Hydrotreating) PHA took place on 4/17/2018 and the actual completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update was 

  2/6/2019.

  7 (MHC/SWS) PHA took place on 6/6/2018 and 3/25/2019 and the expected completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update is 

  7/1/2022 and 

  8 (15MM H2 Plant) PHA took place on 6/4/2018 and the actual completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update was 4/2018.

  9 (5MM H2 Plant) PHA took place on 4/20/2018 and the actual completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update was 

  2/18/2019.

  10 (Caustic Scrubbing) PHA took place on 11/3/2016 and the expected completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update is 

  4/30/2022.

  11 (FGS/Flare/Utilities) PHA took place on 11/4/2016 and 1/31/2017

  12 (Storage) PHA took place on 1/27/2017 and the actual completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update was 1/9/2019.



    Major hazards identified during the PHA process were: toxic release (except; 1, 5, 8, 9, 12)  fire, explosion, runaway reaction (except; 4, 12, 8, 9, 10, 11) overpressurization , corrosion, overfilling, contamination (except; 1, 5, 11) , equipment failure, loss of utilities (except; 6, 10, 11) Polymerization, Earthquakes, floods, tornados and hurricanes was not identified as a major hazard in any process unit(s).  

Process controls in use include: relief valves, check valves, flares, manual shutoffs, automatic shutoffs, interlocks, alarms and procedures, emergency power, vents (except; 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10), Scrubbers (except; 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9, 12), backup pumps (except; 4), grounding equipment (except 4, 12), inhibitor additions (except; 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10, 11, 12), purge system is only present in the Isomerization and Naphtha/Reformer, quench system is only present in Caustic Scrubbing, excess flow device is only present in the FGS/Flare/Utilities, rupture disks are only present in the crude Unit, emergency air supply is only present in the MHC/SWS, Keyed bypass is a process control that is not in use for any of the process units.



    Mitigation systems in use include: Fire water system in all process units, Dikes (except; 1, 3, 5, 6, 11), enclosures are only present in the FGS/Flare/Utilities.



    Monitoring/detection systems in use in all process units include: Process area detectors, perimeter monitors (except; 4) and closed-circuit TVs.



    Changes since the last PHA include: installation of process controls, Installation of process detection systems, installation of perimeter monitoring system, reductions in chemical inventory, increase in chemical inventory. 

    

    Date of most recent review or revision of operating procedures, operating are certified annually and all procedures reviewed on a 3-year cycle. Below is a list of the most recent reviews or revisions of operating procedures:

   

   1 (Isomerization) 9/18/2020

   2 (Crude Unit) 4/30/2020

   3 (Naphtha/Reformer) 10/2/2020  

   4 (Merox Treater) 12/31/2019 Annual Certification

   5 (Polymerization) 7/29/2020

   6 (Hydrotreating) 5/4/2020 

   7 (MHC/SWS) 5/28/2020

   8 (15MM H2 Plant) 8/18/2020

   9 (5MM H2 Plant) 8/12/2020

   10 (Caustic Scrubbing) 6/10/2020

   11 (FGS/Flare/Utilities) FGS 12/31/2019 Annual Certification. Utilities- 5/27/2020



    Date of the most recent review or revision of training programs is the same for all process units as 6/16/2020. The types of training provided are consistent throughout all process units and storage, Classroom, On the job and Computer-based training are provided. Types of competency testing used includes: written test, oral test (except; 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 11), demonstration, observation and response drills (except; 2, 7, 10, 12).

    

        Date of most recent review or revision of maintenance procedures is 9/5/2019 and a full review of all maintenance procedures is ongoing. Below is a list of the date of the most recent equipment inspection or test and the equipment that was most recently inspected or tested.



   1 (Isomerization) D-1403 5/13/2020

   2 (Crude) E-2108B-EX 11/6/2020

   3 (Naphtha/Reformer) D-0408 7/9/2020

   4 (Merox Treater) D-0517 6/9/2020

   5 (Polymerization) D-0201 8/25/2020

   6 (Hydrotreater) D-1702 10/30/2020

   7 (MHC/SWS) E-4121 12/3/2020

   8 (15MM H2 Plant) D-3834 6/12/2020

   9 (5MM H2 Plant) D-2819 10/29/2020

   10 (Caustic Scrubbing) E-1601 6/6/2019

   11 (FGS/Flare/Utilities) D-0720 5/21/2020 / Boiler #2 6/23/2020

   12 (Storage): LP-15 12/8/2020



    Date of most recent changes that triggered management of change procedure was 12/3/2020 and date of most recent Pre-startup review was 8/13/2020.



    Date of most recent compliance audit was 7/9/2020 and expected date of completion of all changes resulting from the most recent audit is 1/31/2022.



    Date of most recent incident investigation was 11/7/2020 and expected completion of all changes resulting from the incident investigation is 12/31/2021.



    Date of most recent review or revision of employee participation plans was 3/24/2020, Hot Work Permit procedure was 1/17/2019, Contractor Safety Procedures was 6/18/2020. Evaluation of contractor safety performance is a continuous but the most recent date was on  12/11/2020.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Calumet Montana Refining, LLC.

Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (40 CFR 68.155 (a))

Calumet Specialty Products Partners LP, owns and operates a petroleum refinery in Great Falls, Montana. Calumet Montana Refining, LLC (CMR) has a long-standing commitment to the safety and health of our community, workers and protection of the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in incident  prevention. Examples include: training personnel and promoting safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. If a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond quickly and effectively to control and mitigate the release. CMR has developed and continuously implements its Process Safety Management (PSM) program and Risk Management Program (RMP) to mitigate potential risks throughout the useful life of its equipment. This Risk Management Plan is intended to comply with the requirements of EPA's Risk Management Program.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED (40 CFR 68.155 (b))

Calumet Montana Refining, LLC operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (i.e., propane, gasoline, jet fuel, diesel fuel, asphalt products, ect.) from raw crude oil. The refinery handles several regulated flammables including propane, butane, isobutane, ethane, N-pentane, isopentane, ect. In addition, the refinery utilizes hydrofluoric acid which is a regulated toxic substance. These substances may exist in pure form or, more commonly, as part of mixtures in varying concentrations. After careful review, for the purpose of this plan, the Refinery operates three (3) covered processes. Calumet Montana Refining, LLC. has decided to modify their plan to include all process units as covered with the exception of our Emulsion Modified Asphalt Plan

t (PMA) and Waste Water Treatment Plant. This change to the plan captures process units that not only exceed flammable and toxic threshold quantities but are also interconnected and co-located. The Alkylation Unit and Fluid Catalytic Cracker (FCC) have been separated out intentionally in preparation for future projects expected to take place at Calumet Montana Refining, LLC.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAIL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS (40CFR 68.155©)

CMR has processes subject to the Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation 1910.119 and the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP).  Calumet Montana Refining, LLC adheres to all applicable federal and state regulatory statutes. The refinery has established programs based on OSHA PSM to evaluate and identify potential risk through management of change, mechanical integrity programs and process hazard assessments.

Actions to minimize potential releases are facilitated by having trained personnel who participate in the programs; the use of qualified contractors; utilizing controlled operating procedures, pre-start-up safety reviews, and established safe work practices. Incidents are investigated and compliance audits performed to periodically assess the programs.  Collectively, incident prevention program activities help prevent potential incident scenarios. In addition to the incident prevention program activities, process safety features exist on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection

?    Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms

?    Hydrofluoric acid detectors with alarms

?    Hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms

?    Personal hydrogen sulfide detectors worn while in the refinery.

Release Containment/Control 

?    Process relief va

lves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases

?    Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated) 

?    Curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases

?    Redundant equipment and instrumentation 

?    Emergency shutdown systems

?    Hydrofluoric acid dump tank

Release Mitigation

Mitigation equipment includes fire suppression and extinguishing systems, as well as an on-site fire truck with foam. Trained and certified hazardous materials emergency response and industrial firefighting personnel are available. In addition, personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus), fire suppression and extinguishing systems are available including automatic and manual systems in the truck loading and unloading areas and the LPG areas.

Additionally, Calumet maintains internal response capabilities with a paid-on-call response team that is trained in industrial firefighting, hazardous materials response and technical rescue. This team is trained in accordance with NFPA and OSHA standards and maintains a presence in the facility 24/7.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (40 CFR 68.155 (d) & 40 CR 68.42(b))

CMR continues to strive to minimize the potential for any releases from our plant.  During the past five (5) years there has been one (1) release of note.  For the non-reportable incidents that have occurred CMR personnel responded swiftly to control and contain each release.  CMR investigates every incident very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring. FCC Fire (NAICS Code 32411)

On March 7, 2019 at 1:35 PM, a vapor cloud ignition occurred due to a release of liquid pressurized gases (LPGs), approximately 2,818 lbs.  The incident resulted from a burst pipe caused by extreme cold weather. It was extinguished in approximately 90 minutes, with minimal onsite impact.  Local responders closed nearby roads.  A precautionary shelter in place was executed offsite but ultimately no

offsite impacts were identified.  Offsite responders were standing by to provide back-up firefighting assistance.

Air monitoring did not detect any environmental release either during or after the incident and no injuries were identified. Primary wind direction originated from the East at an average of 2.5 mph. CMR has conducted a survey to identify any lines or equipment which could be subject to failure due to extremely cold conditions.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE (40 CFR 68.155 (e))

CMR maintains an Emergency Response Plan that is coordinated with the City of Great Falls Fire and Rescue Department to provide a carefully planned and effective response effort. CMR employees are also trained in emergency response to incidents involving hazardous substances and drills are conducted periodically to ensure that the emergency response teams can mitigate the effects from a release.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (40 CFR 68.155 (f))

CMR continues to invest resources in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility.  Continuous implementation of CMR's Process Safety Management (PSM) program and Risk Management Program (RMP) are designed to mitigate potential risks that may arise during the design stage through the useful life of the equipment and improve the safety performance of the facility.
